reviews.text: I fell in love with this beautiful quarter. What I liked most is the variety of bars and restaurants of all kinds. The best part of the city so far.

The Gothic Quarter "Barrio Gotico" with all its narrow streets, squares and famous buildings is part of a visit to Barcelona. It is the oldest district in Barcelona. Many buildings go to the 14th / 15th Century back.
In addition to many shops and boutiques, or the Basilica of Santa María del Mar, in the narrow streets - it is also the place of the Catalan government and the town hall of Barcelona.
Immerse yourself and let yourself drift in the flair.

A tour with a local tourist guide is a great way to learn part of the history of the district, the buildings, and Barcelona, too. It also offers the advantage of being able to concentrate entirely on the surroundings without having to think about where you are. However, during our tour we had caught a tourist guide, who was a bit too much in love with Catalonia. It was very much about the independence and the Catalans - sometimes really too much - so that you have to come back in a friendly way to the buildings and Barcelona. 

The district - fantastic! 
Beautiful architecture, wonderful buildings and good food
Depending on how intense you will watch the buildings, go shopping and eating, I think it takes more than 3 hours to stay there.
Afterwards you can visit the Ramblas.

Great ace to stay in Barcelona had great time lots of interesting shops and fantastic places to eat at every turn. We stayed near harbour ( Hotel Serras) so had great walks . Cable cars are close and Las Rambla.

The most beautiful town! Don't have appropriate words to describe the beauty of this town. So many great places to visit. Town with soul. And definitely, try to find time for Barcelona helicopter tours.

This is the part of the city I stayed when I visited Barcelona.  At first it felt really confusing, but after a few days, I could navigate my way around pretty well.  This is the "old part" of town, so you feel so much more immersed in culture.  Every building was so unique, and all of the alley ways have more fun places to explore!

The Gothic quarter may be famous for the Cathedral but don't miss the Santa Caterina Market and the great food opportunities there. The area is full of museums as well. definitely worth a visit on foot.
Really nice walk through the Gothic old roads. Nice place to have a drink 🍻 or coffee during the day with friends and family.

The Gothic Quarter in Barcelona is a must see for any visitor or resident of Barcelona. There are countless Roman era buildings scattered around every corner. The eclectic variety of shops, restaurants and special one of a kind sights make this area one of the most fascinating in all my world travels.

We did a walking tour of the Gothic Quarter and then went back later in the day and spent the evening here.  It's a great area, full of surprises, narrow streets, great pubs and restaurants, not to mention full of history, politics and churches.
This is the right place to walk around, between the narrow streets, squares and historical buildings.

Personally I think the old Gothic Quarter is the best area in Barcelona.
Taking in the facades of walls and buildings. 
I love the narrow medieval alleyways, with gargoyles peering down at us, and winding our way into the beautiful squares that connect to them. 

Definitely a MUST SEE area of Barcelona
Go there and lose yourself in the narrow streets :)

Had a great time exploring the gothic quarter. We stayed on ramblas and walked though the quarter every day. Just pick a different direction every day and get lost. Stop at as many bodegas as you can and try some tapas, cava and vermouth. Next time we come we will probably stay right in the gothic quarter.  Ramblas is full of tourist traps and there are people bothering you all the time. The born district is also great as well.

A walk in the area is the best way to see this quarter of the city.
Casa de L'Ardiaca (Archdeacon's House) is a 15th century Gothic building with sculptural reliefs and motifs. The mail slot has five swallows and a turtle carved into stone.
Catedral de Santa Eulalia has a facade with arched doorway, many spires & vertical buttresses.  It has an unusual, bright, spacious sanctuary for a Gothic cathedral as it was built on a Paleo-Christian basilica. The museum in Sala Capitular has paintings by Spanish masters.  The cloister's entrance door ia awesome.  Chapel of Santa Lucía is worth seeing.
MUHBA Temple d'August has 4 Corinthian columns in the courtyard which are all that remain of Roman Barcelona's main temple.
Plaça del Rei - Casa Clariana Padellás is a typical medieval urban palace with historical museum, Roman ruins of a heating system, mosaic floors, water & drainage systems.
Nearby is Museu d'Historia de Barcelona. Cappella di Santa Agata - Altare del Connestabile (altarpiece painting), windows with coats-of-arms, mechanical clock.
Museu Picasso in Palau Berenguer d'Aguilar is a Gothic palace  displaying all his works.
Iglesia de Santa Maria del Mar is a Gothic church with decorated facade & main doorway. Interior illuminated by a rose window & stained-glass windows. Icon of Black Madonna in the chapel near left side door.
Palau de la Generalitat is a Gothic architecture building housing all the records of shipments to America from Spain.
Santa Maria del Pí (Blessed Lady of the Pine Tree) is a Gothic church with pointed-arch doorway with statue of Madonna and a large rose window. Interior illuminated by stained-glass windows. Treasury contains sacred art, goldsmith and silversmith works.
Budget about 3 hours to see the Quarter.

Lovely experience to visit this amazing, huge, historical place! While you are standing over there in front of this masterpiece you feel yourself part of world history. Highly recommended to visit it!

We wandered through the old Gothic Quarter, taking in the facades of walls, buildings, and old castles.  Once we found the front of the ancient cathedral (1298), it was, unfortunately, too late to go inside or climb the tower, but at least we got pictures of the outside.  That’s the problem with cruises—not enough time to see everything.  Fortunately, we have traveled to Barcelona on other occasions and spent more time in this wonderful city!  We enjoyed wandering through the narrow medieval alleyways, with gargoyles peering down at us, and winding our way into the beautiful squares that connect to them.  Take time to get lost here!

We love the Gothic quarter in Barcelona. If you’re looking to kill an hour or two and just have a wander around it’s the most beautiful part of Barcelona I think. Most people head for Las Ramblas but I personally think the Gothic quarter is way more real Barcelona. Really take your time and look at all of the architecture the details amazing, such a nice part of the city.

Annual Valentine's Day in April in Barcelona :-)
April 23 is the name day of Saint George, patron of Catalonia.
In Barcelona, it is a day off work and at the same time a combination of Valentine's Day and Book Fair.
Thousands of stands with roses and books on all streets and squares.
Gentlemen buy and give roses to Ladies, Ladies give books to his Man.
In addition, there are many other things happening.
The day is very nice, joyful and really worth seeing.
If you can plan it, then try to be here in this moment.
Anna, Majka, Krzysztof and Ryszard from Poland

We've been lucky enough to visit Barcelona a few times, but the Gothic Quarter is undoubtably our favourite part of this city. Gorgeous architecture, some lovely little shops, and some excellent bars and restaurants.

Simply a must visit.

We stayed at the Hotel Colon (a great hotel, by the way) and so found ourselves across the plaza from the Gothic Cathedral. We enjoyed ambling about the entire district each day discovering new things. This is an ideal place to stay and explore.

Everywhere I went, i seemed to always return here. It's like the heart of Barcelona (at least for a tourist like me). A great place to stroll around and get lost (not that one can get lost for real with Google map), so many things to see, and explored. Loved the winding narrow lanes, a mix of old and new. You can find anything here from traditional crafts, espadrilles, souvenirs, knickknacks, artwork... in the shop house. When tired, just stop at any restaurants, bars, cafe that mushroom around the area.
...that it would be so exciting to see this cathedral as well. Even my 19 years old son found it interesting and important to see it.

The gothic quarter is a great area of Barca full of history with a cathedral museums churches architecture but also loads of shops great traditional little bars,restaurants and one of the best little cake shops ever.you may have to look down the narrow streets but don't be afraid to explore.

Great place to stroll round, just take it all in & enjoy the atmosphere. A must see when in Barcelona. Lots of great little shops, bars & restaurants to enjoy. Very interesting place- take some time to enjoy!

Probably my favourite part of the city
Historic winding streets great restaurants which are a little on the pricey side but well
Worth it for the stunning scenery 
Bubble man outside the cathedral will fir a very small contribution Create fabulous photo opportunity 
Well worth doing one of the ghost tours
The shops and restaurants in the area were unique and enjoyable.  You can get lost in the small streets in a good way.
We stayed in this area near Santa Maria del Mar and loved its charm. Always got lost in the narrow alley-ways and discovered new places.

Very nice to walk around!! Wondefull Gothic Architecture amongst the art nouveau and bauhaus buildings of the rest of Barcelona.
You can spend as much time as you want as it is up to you to choose between strolling around or actually exploring every little street and observe every single building.

The Gothic quarter to the sea was Barcelona until the end of the 19th century. It is the history of Barcelona, from the Royal Atarazanas (13th century), Santa Maria del Mar, The Real square,to  the Cathedral. It is a charming district that has narrow medieval alleys full of trendy bars, pubs and restaurants
An entire experience, getting lost in its streets, having drinks and sharing the experience with friends.
Meandering around, the hours fly by, lovely area, very clean and lots to look at, a Sundau morning well spent.
Just wow, love the architecture! Not too many people around either. I definitely recommend seeing this place.
Great shops cafes very much enjoyed. Recommended . Spent quite a bit it was fun getting lost. At least 3 hours needed

Located in the Gothic area of Barcelona with beautiful architectural designs.  Sadly wasn't open to the public as we went in the evening so couldn't day what the interior was like but we shall be going back ...

The Gothic Quarter is the best place to base yourself in Barcelona in my opinion. Firstly, its very central and only a walk from other attractions. although you do need to take a mode transport to some attractions in the city such as Camp Nou. But you can take one of the Hop On Hop Off buses to get around and also see a lot of the city. 
Secondly, it's a very pretty area with a lot of old architecture and streets which was great to walk around in.
Love the whole atmosphere of this part of Barcelona, so much character and the seafront is lovely.  Would definitely go back.

You can get seriously lost within the Gothic Quarter, but it is absolutely worth going there.

It was fantastic to be able to wander through the warren of avenues and streets, and see some old and unique architecture. The layout itself makes the walk through the quarters an adventure!

This is a unique, old section of Barcelona that is just a joy to explore. I really enjoyed the narrow, cobbled streets and lanes. The stone buildings are full of character. Be sure to visit the Call, which was the small but once vibrant Jewish quarter. There are shops, cafes, restaurants and several small museums/galleries tucked away in these narrow streets.

We recently visited Barcelona and as we were staying near this area decided to have a walk through. Well worth seeing the medieval side streets and small churches. Lots of artisan shops to visit as well 😊
A walkable neighborhood between La Rambla and the Park with winding alleyways and photo opportunities everywhere.  Numerous major cathedrals and other points of interest to see.

It seemed that every outing, every picture perfect location and every highly reviewed eatery would lead us back into the Gothic Quarter. In my opinion, it is what makes Barcelona stand out. It is the heart of Barcelona. You will inevitably find yourself roaming the Gothic quarter several times during your stay in Barcelona. I have found great food, coffee shops, scenery, and even purchased great products at good prices for souvenirs in the Gothic quarters.
A wonderful experience of the marvelous Cathedral de barcelona and the small, narrow gothic streets. the side streets will eventually take you to la rambla.
Have a walk in the evening or take a free walking tour in the morning. Nice surrounding architecture, artisanal shops and plenty of tapas bars included!

Stunning area of Barcelona which I recommend anyone spend some time exploring. 

Found nice places to get coffee and relax and some great shops.
Absolutely must seen in Barcelona! I have seen many similar quarters, but this one is just breathtaking!
Loads of pubs and shops. Narrow lanes weaving in all directions. Easy to get lost and yet not lost enough. Must visit.

Walking around Gótico is always exciting for me even after I have been living here for almost five years. A new bar, restaurant, amazing designed boutique hotel and fresh new graffitis are just part of this unique neighborhood's atmosphere. Get there without a plan and try to get lost around the endless alleies of this old part of Barcelona.

Although it is a crowded place, the stunning architecture leaves you speechless.
This attraction deserves some pictures!

A couple of people had mentioned this place to us so for 7 euros each we headed in, absolutely  stunning, the roof top gave lovely views over the city (on thankfully a sunny day) and the gardens were just and lovely. A must when visiting Barcelona!

the Gothic Quarter is famed for its architecture and have to say its really impressive.  great place to walk around..
If you like teas search for Sans&Sans in the area.. One of a kind..
This is a highlight in BArcelona.  If you dont do anything else.  Get the Rick Steves audio walking tour and find your way around the city.  Get a food tour at night.  Unforgettable.
The Gothic Quarter is really worth a visit. The building is spectacular. We haven't been inside, but still worth it.

Great area to walk around.  Spend most of our second day in Barcelona in this area.  Well worth the time.  The Music hall was a must see, the Cathedral of Barcelona was amazing to see from outside (no tourists permitted inside).  A favorite area of Barcelona.
Amazing place with so much to see and to do there! Lots of places to have fun, have a drink, to explore

This is a fantastic trip into the past going down gothic narrow streets that can go on and on. The are many shops that sell all sorts of things but for me it was the old narrow streets and a labyrinth of streets easy to forget your bearings. At the centre is a great square where you can get a coffee or take a breather and enjoy the atmosphere. Before you can take the path that puts you onto La Rambla for some retail therapy.

Stayed at Hotel Barcelona Catedral right in the middle of the Gothic Quarter it was placed perfectly we walked around, dined in fantastic restaurants, visited quaint bars.  The atmosphere is very lively with lots going on.  Would recommend to everyone
What a great place to visit! We loved the history of these buildings and the atmosphere...like going back in time! We rented an apartment there and that was cool.
visit emptynestersinparis on IG for photos, videos!  buy souvenirs, take beautiful photos, eat and shop!
Awesome neighborhood. Great atmosphere, nice walking, many and stylish shops over there. Bohemian place

What an awesome area to explore while in barcelona. So many amazing Gothic style buildings and pieces of architectures to check out. There are also plenty of great resturants and cafes to check out and sample some local food at. You could spend a week here or just a day or 2, all depends on what and how much you want to do. Enjoy your trip.
The Barri Gotic lived up to the hype.  We especially enjoyed experiencing a live sardana dance in front of the cathedral.  I think these occur most Sundays around 11:00.
Absolutely beautiful historical architecture, but please be aware of your surroundings as pickpockets operate in this area

The Gothic Quarter in Barcelona is simply stunning. Its filled with amazing buildings at every turn.  Great selection of restaurants & bars & shops etc. Felt very safe walking around the side streets at night time.

The best way to see it is to take a self guided walking tour. There are many audio guides to follow through Lonely Planet guide or Rick  Steves audio tours. We watch You Tube videos, mainly Rick Steves, before visiting a city. Lonely Planet guide had recommended walking tours of the area but we took lots of little detours when a street or neighbourhood looked interesting.

The Gothic Quarter is stunning.  Quaint little streets with something around each corner.  Plenty of architecture and stunning buildings.  I loved this part of Barcelona.  You will also find small shops selling those little gifts.
Great place, small and big at the same time. It has it all, ancient ruins, museums, atmospheric alleys, shops, bars and restaurants. We loved it at any time of day and night.

We were in Barcelona for 6 days and visited the Gothic Quarter several times as it was an awesome place to wander around and find a unique bar, or restuatrant, or store. There are also several historic places to visit.

Worth a visit; in fact I can't imagine going to Barcelona without visiting here. Not everything is what it seems...some things that look very old are relatively new. But scenes like the scarred walls of the schoolyard Plaça de Sant Felip Neri from bombing during the civil war, or a staircase associated with Columbus, or even a great breakfast chocolate place, make visiting here a must do.
Labrynthian, and you can easily get lost. Plus, getting around requires walking as cars don't traverse much here.
We did a food tour through here, and the tapas were great. Bring your camera, drink some vermouth, eat some jamon, and enjoy!

The gothic quarter is rich in character and architecture. Its easy to lose your sense of directions and come across some unexpected gems hidden in the narrow streets. I would have given the Quarter 5 stars but for the drug dealers trying to sell their wares.

Better to walk this bit and soak up the ancient streets and narrow alleyways. The cathedral is a masterpiece. Lots of old shops & squares to enjoy along the way. Needs a full day to explore. Watch your belongings as pickpockets are rife.
You have  go there .. Its the heart of the city .. Its a trip to the past ... We went there 3 times and it wasnt enough ...Every time you will discover something new to see..
Essential visit for Barcelona to give you a true flavour of the old town but be sure to take a free working tour from Runnerbean.
We enjoyed walking through the Gothic Quarter and marveling at the architecture of the buildings. Of course, there are many shops, but it did not have a touristy atmosphere.
The thing I most enjoyed was see all the Spanish families out and stumbling across a ruin in the center of the district. The Cathedral was lovely too.
Terrific place to wander and stroll, safe, pretty clean and always interesting never dull. Find bars, tapas and interesting outlets. Open more at night.
Nice place with narrow streets with bars, shops and restaurants to explore. Plenty of amazing architecture . Don’t forget to look up!

You could take a free (just tip him/her at the end) walking tour with a local guide through the area, and they will give you some good information and history. Or, you can simply walk through the area yourself, and still have a great experience. Just get off of the main streets and explore. You'll find amazing places, restaurants, etc., and your day will fly by very quickly.
Every little side road was something to behold in terms of architecture, beauty, quirky shops and lovely restaurants. We loved it!

This is a must-see area - even my husband said so and he complains about me taking his all over the city to see such and such museum, church, statue, library etc. The history is right there in front of you, a quarter that shows how people lived almost on top of each other, washing lines a plenty, food and wine choices to tempt you and ice-cream to cool you down. I recommend Las Fritas !

I booked a hotel in this area abd probably paid an unnecessary premium.  The area is ok with the proverbial squares and churches but its all within walking distance so staying outside the area would be my choice if i went again

If you are in Barcelona as a first timer or regular or a resident, it is a place you can see the real pulse of the city, very old stunning but narrows walks, lots of small shops and great restaurants and activities. I say this is the real heart of BCN.
It's a place worth visiting. The best way to get to know is to go through it and get lost its little streets. Shopping is also amazing!
We loved it down here, the energy the architecture, the people.  What a great place to explore!  Don't miss the Gaudi apartment and the great buildings all around it.

There isn’t anything more romantic than walking along a windy street looking at beautiful gothic architecture. Romantic trip away or not this is a great location to stay in. You will find a mix of cool independent shops, cafes, not to mention the stunning cathedral, and funky gift shops. It is definitely worth a visit.

The best part of Barcelona.

Watch your belongings.

I enjoyed the walk, the beautiful scenery and of course shops near by.
The (in)famous Barri Gòtic is an amazing neighbourhood to walk through. Yes, there are a lot of tourist traps. But if you look good, you can find some hidden gems!
It was a very nice neighborhood to walk around. It has many places to see such as the cathedral. It is a must to visit when traveling to Barcelona
Plan to spend a lot of time here with so many interesting things to see. The cathedral, the plaza, and the city walls, all worth a visit. Even the shops in this area are unique.
Lovely building inside and out. With lots of lovely entertainment outside in the square on Sunday, with adorable children performing their National folk dancing
A proper visit to Barcelona must include a good walk around the Gothic Quarter. The cathedral is also a must.

This is a great area to walk around and get lost in as you get to see everything the gothic quarter has to offer. The architecture is amazing and the streets make you feel you are not in a modern city. The little shops and restaurants are get to explore in the area.

The meandering narrow streets with shops and restaurants at every turn is not to be missed. There are many hidden squares to visit. Prices in the bars ate reasonable.  Find 'Story',  if you ate a bibliophile you won't be disappointed.
This area has small narrow street, small shop, souvenirs shops.  Also closed to Barcelona cathedral..

You really need to put this place on your list. Maybe the most beautiful place in this area is square where Gothic Cathedral is. Everything is very clean, architecture is amazing. Musicians are everywhere. In love with all streets here. Beautiful nature with beautiful buildings. Enjoy in beautiful details.

What an adventure - this beautiful area is full of beautiful and historic architecture! Worthy of a relaxing stroll to see such treasures. ( was rescued by my cell phone GPS many times to find our way out)

I’m not sure what the actual boundaries are of the gothic quarter, and maybe they aren’t rigidly defined. But you’ll know it if you’re in it because much of the architecture will have that medieval feel to it. There are statues and basilicas and so many cool, narrow alleys. 

Be aware that it is a popular area for tourists, so it will always be crowded. And because the streets are narrow that could lead to some frustration. We went in January so it wasn’t too bad but I can imagine a more popular month being a little harder to get around. 

Expect a lot of graffiti. Like Rome, it seems to be everywhere. But most of it seems to be more of the artistic variety as opposed to gang markings. Every single roll down metal store front is a canvas (not just in this quarter, but throughout Barcelona) to the point that I wonder if many of these are commissioned.
One of my favorite parts of the city... Just be careful with your belongings as there are lots of thieves.

They may charge  to the Cathedral, yet you can still enjoy walking on your own around the Gothic Quarter and even if lucky see an actual "Sardinia" traditional dance. A lot of the locals are welcoming, yet forewarned-keep an eye on your valuables. Plenty of picturesque architecture mixed with minimal modern additions and make certain you have comfortable shoes (and maybe a disposable poncho for those frequent/surprise shower drops) and just enjoy your stroll at your own pace.

We had an AirBnB whithin the Gothic Quarter and it was perfect. Easily walkable and many café options. Restaurants are a bit touristic and a bit many scammers. But still a fab place to stay and stroll around in.

The gothic quarter is a beautiful labyrinth of streets and plazas insulated from the outside world. We wandered every day through a different part and never got bored. The last day of our trip, we rented electric bikes and buzzed around which was so much fun and we could identify the places we'd already walked to. 

The shops nestled in the gothic quarter were small but they were lovely - all of the souvenirs (and my scarf) we bought from those small shops.

It’s studied abroad in Barcelona for 5 months and lived in the heart of the gothic quarter. Every street is lined with cafes and more. I once stumbled into an amazing free art museum without even trying. Every building is beautiful and there’s many squares where locals grab drinks and dinners and enjoy the open air. One of my favorite places in the whole world. And this is coming from someone who’s travelled internationally most of her life. Although beware of pickpockets
Quaint, fun stores, great restaurants old city feel. Not to miss if in Barcelona. Would recommend staying in a hotel or AbB here if u can.
We stayed in the Barri Gotic which was a lovely are to walk in or visit interesting places, plus easy to access Place de la Catalunya for transport links to other areas or the airport.

We wondered up and down the streets, amazed at the architecture and huge buildings do close to each other.
We stopped to drink at some of the little cafes and tapas bars to soak up the atmosphere.

We really enjoyed our walk in the Gothic quarter together with Santa Eulalia s cathedral. (sometime is free to visit, or 7 euro cost). We took a tour to this quarter and we found out a lot about it so it is a must when in Barcelona.
lovely small streets, small local shops with art and clothing that you won`t find in other places, wonderful coffee places and sweets and the best architecture- what is not to love about this place?

One of the highlights of a visit to Barcelona is a stroll through the Gothic Quarter stopping to visit the cathedral, the Boqueira markets, the Basillica of Santa Maria and of course a stroll along Las Ramblas.  The narrow streets are a delight with interesting shops, cafes and restaurants.  Recommend.

Beautiful buildings to see here. Many old churches/cathedrals. Every little street has something interesting to see if it’s architecture you’re looking for. Loved the old wrought iron balconies on some buildings and the really old solid studded wooden doors. Very Gothic.... lives up to its name.
Architecture is absolutely brilliant lots to look at and plenty to do your constantly looking at buildings
The Gothic Quarter is a must when visiting Barcelona. Getting lost is ok. The streets are clean and if you visit in January like we did, it's not crowded.
The cathedral building was really amazing. Big number of tourists were there enjoying take pictures. The cafe and restaurants around were so good.
The best area in all of Barcelona.  So much to do, see, eat and drink.  A great area to stay and explore.

Beautiful church it was very Gothic in design. It was really interesting to see after spending the morning at the Sagrada familia. The columns are stunning and the darkness really brings the candle light into perspective. Beautiful
it's amazing to be able to walk in the small alleys and Guinness in Barcelona it felt like I was back in mediaeval times 3 and amazing
Just walk in a narrow, old streets of Barcelona and enjoy. It takes aprox. 2 hours. Behind the Cathedral you can find the pizzeria Nani. Cheap and delicious...

Fell in love immediately..the buildings are so beautiful and its lovely to see the history of Barcelona. Lots of lovely places to eat and shops for all sorts.. Take your camera I hope you'll fall in love as I did
Loved just walking the streets of the Gothic quarter, there was so much culture such beautiful buildings. Every small turn was a pleasant new surprise
Enjoyed wandering through the Gothic Quarter without any destination in mind.  So many wonderful little pastry shops.  Happened upon a great restaurant for tapas and paella.
We stayed at the Hotel Gótico which was in the quarters. We did have time to do a formal waling tours but did a lot of walking in the area and was just awesome soaking up the history.

Really worth a visit.
Beautiful carvings and paintings.
We attended during the morning no queues and didn’t have to pay free between certain times in the morning and afternoons.
Didn’t pay to go up the tower as short of time but if you did think it was only a few euros.

Nice area to walk around, standard European city area really. 
Lots of nice restaurants but the shops were all the same with tourist things
We loved walking the area and visiting the many shops and restaurants that line the area. We spent hours here, so allocate some time here on your stop.

If you are claustrophobic then do not walk through these streets.  The architecture is timeless and absolutely beautiful.  I like to get lost in the side streets and wonder between the gothic and borne and try to go down the streets that are less travelled.  You can find excellent bars and restaurants so do not settle for the tourist traps.
Almost every day I find myself back wandering through the narrow alleys of the Gothic quarter. It is like slipping through a doorway in time. I love it.
It's amazing to visit all these places. The architecture and the culture is absolutely stunning.  You don't have to book ticket from agencies  or anywhere. Just go there.
Tons of shops, bars, interesting buildings. I really liked to walk around the streets. Saw a lot of street artists also
The history, the vibe, the picturesque corners and squares- won’t be disappointed spending part of your trip here.
We walked around this area by the cathedral and the narrow side streets. It was interesting to see how it must have looked 100+ years ago.

Many tour groups take people around the Gothic Area but having an official guide from the Bureau was perfect.  He was very informative and when we were done recommended a locals lunch spot frequented by government workers.  Thank you for sharing this beautiful part of your city

Enjoyed it very much 😊
In front of the Cathedral there is a nice coffee on the roof of hotel with a great view on the city!

Amazing architecture, shops & eateries. We allowed ourselves to get lost in the streets & allys of the Gothic Quarter during the day. We were still cautious & went down streets where we saw multiple people. But pretty much every turn there's cute little shops & food places. It felt like we were walking around the Universal Studios backlot.
There are many nice and interesting houses to see in the Gothic Quarter. Take your time to stroll through the narrow streets and enjoy the atmosphere...
Beautiful historic cathedral surrounded by a medieval area full of shops and eateries. Don't miss the swans in the cathedral's courtyard.

Take a free walking tour of the Gothic quarter for two hours from 11am any day in Barcelona and be transported into another world. Your guide will show you all sorts of hidden gems and you will enjoy uncovering some of the lesser known places in this fascinating city. And yes, it is free!

A very beautiful neighborhood Frozen in time. It has so many things to do and see inside and a great place to get lost inside the alleys. Don't be so naive though and explore them without thinking about the pickpockets. They are everywhere and they watch your every move.
Lovely area to walk around all day and visit lots of churches, museums, shops and bars. Easily fill a whole day here

I spent majority of yesterday afternoon and this morning exploring the Gothic Quarter. I had with me some cards that essentially took me on a walking tour of the quarter. It was fascinating seeing the influences that shaped Barcelona, ranging from original structures from the Roman Empire to medieval times to modern day influences. Plus, the gothic quarter is filled with so many cute shops (I was tempted many times to spend money I definitely don’t have!). For those who get hungry, there’s also a wide range of food options available. Sites like the cathedral are worth a visit, but it’s also definitely worth just wandering the streets and getting a bit lost in them

Great area to stay in Barcelona.As the oldest part of the city the Barri Gothic is full of interest with lots of historic churches and buildings to visit. The narrow streets and beautiful balconies add to its charm as do the many small restaurants and tapas bars.It's also a great base to explore the city on foot.

This is the oldest part of Barcelona featuring churches and palaces built in the midieval times. The Barcelona Cathedral, Royal Plaza, Viceroy's Palace are all part of this area full of narrow lanes and bylanes. It is very easy to get lost here without a guide.
Walking around Gothic Quarter was so amazing and  enjoyably.  Narrow  cobbled streets , medieval signs, picturesque  windows .  I would recommend to  take a tour with a tour guide.

Beautiful gothic buildings and façades in the middle of one of Europe's most modern and dynamic capitals. It's worth to take it slow and stop at every corner, admiring the beauty of the old behemoths still standing. And don't worry, there're plenty of small bars around to replenish your energy if you feel low.

The gothic quarter hosts some hidden places that are even unknown by Barcelonans like me. One of this places is the "Sant Felip Neri" square. Gothic Quarter  (Barri Gotic) is at the heart of Central Barcelona and it is one of the best places to go if you want to stroll along the narrow medieval streets in Barcelona. Gothic Quarter was used to be the Roman village and it has over 2,000 years of history. Nowadays, it has a good mixture of old and new. It has the most famous Barcelona Catherdral, museums, the Bridge of Sighs, Placa Reial, plus a series of Catalan restaurants, traditional cafes and trendy bars. It's so easy to access as it is located in between Liceu, Catalunya, Urqyinaona and Jaume I metro stations. (The nearest station is Jaume I) La Rambla and the Museu Picasso are also just minutes away from the Quarter.

The mural was installed as part of the commemoration of the Tricentenary of the fall of Barcelona in 1714 in the War of the Spanish Succession.
